entry.title: MicroservicesGuide-èµ°è¿‘å¾®æœåŠ¡
entry.content:
å‰è¨€

Nothing better than a buzy Saturday morning.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆæƒ³è¦ç¿»è¯‘è¿™ç¯‡åšå®¢å‘¢ï¼Œå› ä¸ºä¹Ÿæ˜¯çœ‹äº†bç«™ä¸Šçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­¦ä¹ springbootçš„ä¸€ä¸ªè§†é¢‘ï¼Œè€Œä¸”æˆ‘ä»Šå¤©é¢è¯•çš„æ—¶å€™äººå®¶é—®äº†å¾®æœåŠ¡æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œç„¶åç”±æ­¤å¯å¾—æˆ‘ä¸‡åˆ†åæ‚”æ²¡æœ‰å½“æ—¶é€šç¯‡ç¿»è¯‘è¿™ç¯‡åšå®¢ã€‚
å¥½äº†ç°åœ¨åæ‚”ä¹ŸæŒ½æ•‘ä¸äº†æˆ‘çš„æ„šä¸å¯åŠäº†ã€‚
è§‚çœ‹ç¬”è®°ï¼šhttps://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1Eg4y187XT
å°±æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªè§†é¢‘å‘Šè¯‰äº†æˆ‘ï¼šæ¨èçœ‹å“¦~
ä¸ºäº†ä¸åæ‚”ï¼Œä»¥åæ¯ä»¶äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œèƒ½åšç¬”è®°å°±ä¸€å®šè¦å‹ç€è‡ªå·±åšï¼Œä¸ç„¶ä¼šåæ‚”çš„ï¼›

Microservices Guide å¾®æœåŠ¡æŒ‡å—ï¼ˆç¿»è¯‘ï¼‰

é“¾æ¥ï¼šhttps://www.martinfowler.com/microservices/

A guide to material on martinfowler.com about microservices.
Matin Fowler
21 Aug 2019

Microservices Guide

Contents

In short , the microservice architectural style is an approach to developing a single application as a suite of small services , each running in its own process and communicating with lightweight mechanisms , often an HTTP resource API .
These services are built around business capabilities and independently deployable by fully automated deployment machinery .
There is a bare minimum of centralized management of these services , which may be written in different programming languages and use different data storage technologies .
â€“ James Lewis and Martin Fowlerï¼ˆ2014ï¼‰

Introduce - Martin Fowler

äº†è§£å¾®æœåŠ¡ä¹‹å‰é¦–å…ˆæ¥çœ‹çœ‹Martin Fowlerè€çˆ·å­çš„è‡ªæˆ‘ä»‹ç»ï¼›
Fowleråˆšè¢«æˆ‘æ‰“æˆäº†Flowerï¼›

ç®€ä»‹é“¾æ¥ï¼šhttps://www.martinfowler.com

Contents

Software development is a young profession , and we are still learning the techniques and building the tools to do it effectively .
Iâ€™ve been involved in this activity for over three decades and in the last two Iâ€™ve been writing on this website about patterns and practives that make it easier to build userful software .
The site began as a place to put my own writing , but I also use it to publish articles by my colleagues .

In 2000 , I joined ThoughtWorkds , where my role is to learn about the techniques that weâ€™ve learned to deliver software for our clients , and pass these techniques on to the wider software industry .
As this site has developed into a respected platform on software development , Iâ€™ve edited and published articles by me colleagues , both ThoughtWorkers and others , to help useful writing reach a wider audience .

A website on building software effectively

A website on building software effectively

Contents

If thereâ€™s a theme that runs through my work and writing on this site , itâ€™s the interplay between the shift towards agile thinking and the technical patterns and practices that make agile software development practical .
While specifics of technology change rapidly in our profession , fundamental practices and patterns are more stable .
So writing about these allows me to have articles on this site that are several years old but still as relevant as when they were written .

As software becomes more critical to modern business , software needs be able to react quickly to changes , allowing new features to be be conceived , developed and put into production rapidly .
The techniques of agile software development began in the 1990s and became steadily more popular in the last decade .
The focus on a flexible approach to planning , which allows software products to change direction as the userâ€™s needs change and as product managers learn more about how to make their users effective .
While widely accepted now , agile approaches are not easy , requiring significant skills for a team , but more importantly a culture of open collaboration both within the team and with a teamâ€™s partners .

This need to respond fluently to changes has an important impact upon the architecture of a software system.
The software needs to be built in such a way that it is able to adapt to unexpected changes in features .
One of the most important ways to do this is to write clear code , making it easy to understant what the program is supposed to do .
This code should be devided into modules which allow developers to understand only the parts of the system they need to make a change .
This production code should be supported with automated tests that can detect any errors made when making a change while providing examples of how internal structures are used .
Large and complex software efforts may find the microservices architectural style helps teams deploy software with less entangling dependencies .

Creating software that has a good architecture isnâ€™t something that can be done first time .
Like good prose , it needs regular revisions and programmers learn more about what the product needs to do and how best to design the product to achieve its goals .
Refactoring is an essential technique to allow a program to be changed safety .
It consists of making small changes that donâ€™t alter the observable behavior of the software .
Bt combining lots of small changes , developers can revise the softwareâ€™s structure supporting significant modifications that werenâ€™t planned when the system was first conceived .

Software that runs only on a developerâ€™s machine isnâ€™t providing value to the customers of the software .
Traditionally releasing software has been a long and complicated process , one that hinders the need to evolve software quickly .
Continuous Delivery uses automation and collaborative workflows to remove this bottleneck , allowing teams to release software as often as the customers demand .
For Continuous Delivery to be possible , we need to build in a solid foundation of Testing , with a range of automated tests that can give us confidence taht our changes havenâ€™t introduced any bugs .
This leads us to integrate testing into programming , which can act to improve our architectural .

Photostream

Data Management

Contents

There are many kinds of softeare out there , the kind Iâ€™m primarily engaged is Enterprise Applications .
One of the enduring problems we need to tackle in this world is data management .
The aspectes of data management Iâ€™ve focused on here are how to migrate data stores as their applications respond to changing needs , coping with different contexts across a large enterprice , the role of NoSQL databases , and the broader issues of coping with data that is both Big and Messy .

Domain-Specific Languages

Contents

A common problem in complex software systems is how to capture complicated domain logic in a way that programmers can both easily manipulate and also easily communicate to domain experts .
Domain-Specific Languages(DSLs) create a custom language for a particular problem , either with custom parsers or by conventions within a host language .

Books

Contents

Iâ€™ve written seven books on software development , including Refactoring , Patterns of Enterprise Application Architectural , and UML Distilled .
Iâ€™m also the editor of a signature series for Addison-Wesley that includes five jolt award winners .
My Books Pageâ€¦

Conference Talks

Contents

Iâ€™m often asked to give talks at conferences , from which Iâ€™ve inferred that Iâ€™m a pretty good speaker - which is ironic since I really hate giving talks .
You can form your own opinion of my talks by watching videos of some my conference talks .
My Videos Pageâ€¦

Board Games

Contents

Iâ€™ve long been a fan of board games , I enjoy a game that fully occupies my mind , clearing out all the serious thoughts for a bit , while enjoying the company of good friends .
Modern board games saw dramatic improvement in the 1990â€™s with the rise of Eurogames , and I expect many people would be surprised if they havenâ€™t tried any of this new generation .
I also appear regularly on Heavy Cardboard .
My Board Games pageâ€¦

entry.title: Shopping for a TV
entry.content:
Learn & Talk I

Chapter 1 Shopping

Lesson 4 Shopping for a TV

at the bottom of the following pages:T1=teaching instructions;T=teacher;S=student

Contents

  • part A. Letâ€™s Learn (12 mins)

  • part B. Letâ€™s Talk (12 mins)

  • part C. Review (1 min)

Learning Objectives

part A. Letâ€™s Learn

Vocabulary (4 mins)

warranty a written promise from a company to repair or replace a product that develops a fault within a particular period of time ä¿ä¿®å•ï¼Œä¿ä¿®å¡ï¼Œä¿ä¿®æœåŠ¡ e.g. The TV has a 3-year warranty.
best-seller a new bool or other product that has sold a great number of copies. çƒ­å–å“ï¼Œç•…é”€å“ e.g. As a writer, he wants to write a best-seller.
offer to provide or supply something. æä¾› e.g. He offered me a glass of water.
delivery the act of taking goods,letters,parcels,etc. to people's houses or places of work è¿é€ï¼Œé€’é€ e.g. They offer free delivery, so it's a good deal. deliver(v.) The letter was delivered yesterday,

Dialog

Role-play the dialog with your teacher twice,and learn the highlighted expressions by heart.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·åˆ†è§’è‰²æœ—è¯»ä¸¤éä¸€ä¸‹å¯¹è¯ã€‚ç†Ÿè®°æ ‡äº®éƒ¨åˆ†çš„çŸ­è¯­å’Œè¡¨è¾¾

ï¼ˆJohn and Anne are shopping for a TV.ï¼‰

Anne: How about this one?
John: I like this brand ,and the price isnâ€™t too high.
ï¼ˆThey start to ask the salesperson for information.ï¼‰
John: How long is the warranty for this TV?
Salesperson: It comes with a 2-year parts(é›¶ä»¶)warranty. Itâ€™s also the best-seller now.
Anne: Do you offer free delivery?
Anne: Yes, we do.

part B. Letâ€™s Talk

Conversation

Suppose youâ€™re shopping for appliances. Use th vocabulary and expressions youâ€™ve learned in part A to complete the following conversation. å‡è®¾ä½ æ­£åœ¨é€‰è´­ç”µå™¨ã€‚è¿ç”¨åœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å­¦åˆ°çš„è¯æ±‡å’Œè¡¨è¾¾å°†ä¸€ä¸‹æƒ…å¢ƒå¯¹è¯è¡¥å……å®Œæ•´

Hints
delivery
warranty
How long is the warranty for â€¦?
best-seller
offer

A: Excuse me. How along is warranty for this air conditioner(ç©ºè°ƒ) ?
B: Three years. Itâ€™s the best-seller now. We also offer free delivery.
A: But thereâ€™s an air conditioner of this brand in the living room of my house,and it doesnâ€™t work very well recently.
B: Weâ€™ll offer free repair(ç»´ä¿®) if itâ€™s still under warranty.
A: Fine.

Discussion

Talk with your teacher about the following question. Refer to the hints if necessary.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·è®¨è®ºä¸€ä¸‹é—®é¢˜ã€‚å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒæ–¹æ¡†ä¸­çš„æç¤º

  1. How often do you watch TV? When do you usually watch TV?

Hints:

every day / usually / from time to time(å¶å°”) / never â€¦
in the evening(morning ,afternoon) / at the noon / on weekends â€¦

  1. What kind of TV programs(èŠ‚ç›®) do you like ? Why?

Hints:

news -> learn whatâ€™s happening around the world â€¦
talk shows(è®¿è°ˆèŠ‚ç›®) -> know more about the life of famous people â€¦
variety shows (ç»¼è‰ºèŠ‚ç›®) -> funny,interesting ,relaxing(ä»¤äººæ”¾æ¾çš„) â€¦

  1. What will you consider(è€ƒè™‘) when buying an appliance(ç”µå™¨)ï¼Ÿ

Hints:

brands (what brands?) / prices (how much?) / warranty(how long?) ã€ delivery (free or not?) â€¦.

In this lesson,youâ€™ve learned

  1. words about â€œbuying appliancesâ€

warranty
best-seller
offer
delivery

  • commonly used expressions for buying appliances

How long is the warranty for this TV?
Do you offer free delivery?

  • how to talk about TV and other appliances

Further Study

Listen and Learn

electric oven ç”µçƒ¤ç®±
dishwasher æ´—ç¢—æœº

  • The soybean milk machine(è±†æµ†æœº)/ juicer(æœæ±æœº) has excellent features such as low cost, complete function,convenient to use and so on.

entry.title: In the Supermarket
entry.content:
Learn & Talk I

Chapter 1 Shopping

Lesson 3 In the Supermarket

at the bottom of the following pages:T1=teaching instructions;T=teacher;S=student

Contents

  • part A. Letâ€™s Learn (12 mins)

  • part B. Letâ€™s Talk (12 mins)

  • part C. Review (1 min)

Learning Objectives

part A. Letâ€™s Learn

Vocabulary (4 mins)

vocabulary means sentense etc phrase
toothbrush a small brush with a long handle that you use to clean your teeth e.g. How much is the toothbrush . toothpaste ç‰™è†ï¼›mouthwash æ¼±å£æ°´
promote to encourage people to like,buy,use,do,or support something å®£ä¼ ï¼Œä¿ƒé”€ e.g. The saleswoman is promoting cookies. promotion n.ä¿ƒé”€ï¼ˆoften on posters å¸¸åšæµ·æŠ¥æ ‡è¯­ï¼‰
include to contain something as a part of something else,or to make something part of something else åŒ…æ‹¬ e.g. This gift pack(ç¤¼åŒ…) includes toothbrushes,toothpaste, and mouthwash.
aisle a long,narrow space between the rows of shelves in a large shop ï¼ˆå•†åº—è´§æ¶é—´çš„ï¼‰é€šé“ e.g. Youâ€™ll find toothbrushes in the fourth aisle .

Dialog

Role-play the dialog with your teacher twice,and learn the highlighted expressions by heart.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·åˆ†è§’è‰²æœ—è¯»ä¸¤éä¸€ä¸‹å¯¹è¯ã€‚ç†Ÿè®°æ ‡äº®éƒ¨åˆ†çš„çŸ­è¯­å’Œè¡¨è¾¾

ï¼ˆMark is choosing a gift for His girlfriend in a jewelry(ç å®) store.ï¼‰
  • Salesman: Have a look at these toothbrushes.They are being promoted in this gift pack now.
  • Mark: Whatâ€™s included in the gift pack ?
  • Salesman: Toothbrushes,toothpaste,mouthwash and a cup .
  • Mark: Itâ€™s good deal. Where can i find shower gel(æ²æµ´éœ²).
  • Salesman: Itâ€™s in aisle 10.

Itâ€™s good deal. ç›´è¯‘ï¼šè¿™æ˜¯ç¬”å¥½äº¤æ˜“./æ„è¯‘ï¼šè¿™æŒºåˆ’ç®—çš„.

part B. Letâ€™s Talk

Conversation

Suppose youâ€™re choosing a gift in a jewelry store. Use th vocabulary and expressions youâ€™ve learned in part A to complete the following conversation. å‡è®¾ä½ åœ¨å•†åº—é‡ŒæŒ‘ç¤¼ç‰©ã€‚è¿ç”¨åœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å­¦åˆ°çš„è¯æ±‡å’Œè¡¨è¾¾å°†ä¸€ä¸‹æƒ…å¢ƒå¯¹è¯è¡¥å……å®Œæ•´

Hints
aisle
Itâ€™s good deal
toothbrush
Whatâ€™s included in the pack?
promote

  • A: Excuse me. Where can i find toothbrush ?
  • B: In aisle 4. Follow me.
  • A: Thanks.
  • B: Have a look at this pack. Itâ€™s being promote and it is selling well.
  • A: Whatâ€™s included in the pack ?
  • B: Toothbrushes,toothpaste and mouthwash. Theyâ€™re only 25 yuan in total(åˆè®¡).
  • A: Itâ€™s good deal.

Discussion

Talk with your teacher about the following question. Refer to the hints if necessary.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·è®¨è®ºä¸€ä¸‹é—®é¢˜ã€‚å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒæ–¹æ¡†ä¸­çš„æç¤ºã€‚

  • 1.When are things in the supermarket promoted in your city? Will you by a lot when theyâ€™re being promoted? Why?

Hints:
around hoildays like Christmas,Womenâ€™s Dayâ€¦
will by a lot->cheap/Itâ€™s a good dealâ€¦
wonâ€™t buy a lot->waste

Hints:
toothbrushes
aisle
promoted
Whatâ€™s included in the pack
Itâ€™s a good deal

  • 2.How often do you go to the supermarket? What do you usually buy in the supermarket?

Hints:
every day/every week/when i need to buy
thins/once in a while(æ—¶ä¸æ—¶ï¼Œå¶å°”)â€¦
bread/fruit/drinks/showr gelâ€¦

  • Have you ever bought(buyçš„è¿‡å»åˆ†è¯) things in an online supermarket? Do you like it? Why or Why not?

Hints:
yes->anytime and anywhere / no need to carry the heavy shopping bagsâ€¦
no->wait for days for things to comeâ€¦

part c. Review

In this lesson,youâ€™ve learned

  • 4 words about â€œshopping in the supermarketâ€

  • commonly used expressions for buying gifts

Whatâ€™s included in the gift pack?

Further Study

entry.title: Choosing a Gift
entry.content:
Learn & Talk I

Chapter 1 Shopping

Lesson 2 Choosing a Gift

at the bottom of the following pages:T1=teaching instructions;T=teacher;S=student

Contents

  • part A. Letâ€™s Learn (12 mins)

  • part B. Letâ€™s Talk (12 mins)

  • part C. Review (1 min)

Learning Objectives

part A. Letâ€™s Learn

Vocabulary (4 mins)

vocabulary means sentense etc
look for to try to find something or someone å¯»æ‰¾ï¼ˆæŸç‰©/æŸäººï¼‰ e.g. Theyâ€™re looking for insects in the field.
have something in mind to think of (æƒ³èµ·ï¼Œæœ‰â€¦æƒ³æ³•) e.g. What do you have in mind ?
how about (doing) something used to introduce a new subject which you think is relevant to the conversation â€¦æ€ä¹ˆæ · e.g. 1.How about a cup of coffee ? 2.How about going to the cinema ?
gift-wrap to wrap as a gift,with decorative pape,ribbon,etcï¼ˆused as verbï¼‰ e.g. Sheâ€™s gift-wrapping the chocolate. gift wrapping ç¤¼å“çš„åŒ…è£…ï¼ˆåŠ¨åè¯ï¼‰ ã€ wrapping paper ç¤¼å“åŒ…è£…çº¸

Dialog

Role-play the dialog with your teacher twice,and learn the highlighted expressions by heart.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·åˆ†è§’è‰²æœ—è¯»ä¸¤éä¸€ä¸‹å¯¹è¯ã€‚ç†Ÿè®°æ ‡äº®éƒ¨åˆ†çš„çŸ­è¯­å’Œè¡¨è¾¾

ï¼ˆMark is choosing a gift for His girlfriend in a jewelry(ç å®) store.ï¼‰
  • Salesman: Good evening, sir, can i help you ?
  • Mark: Yeah! Iâ€™m looking for a gift for my girlfriend.
  • Salesman: Do you have something in mind ?
  • Mark: I think a necklace(é¡¹é“¾) would be perfect.
  • Salesman: How about this one ? It sells very well.
  • Mark: Sounds good, but could you gift-wrap this,please ?
  • Salesman: Sure.

part B. Letâ€™s Talk

Conversation

Suppose youâ€™re choosing a gift in a jewelry store. Use th vocabulary and expressions youâ€™ve learned in part A to complete the following conversation. å‡è®¾ä½ åœ¨å•†åº—é‡ŒæŒ‘ç¤¼ç‰©ã€‚è¿ç”¨åœ¨ç¬¬ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å­¦åˆ°çš„è¯æ±‡å’Œè¡¨è¾¾å°†ä¸€ä¸‹æƒ…å¢ƒå¯¹è¯è¡¥å……å®Œæ•´

Hints
Could you gift-wrap this?
How about this necklace?
look for
(not)have anything in mind

  • A: Can I help you, sir/madam?
  • B: Yes,Iâ€™m look for a gift for my mother, but i donâ€™t have anything in mind.
  • A: How about this necklace? It;s beautiful and perfect as a gift.
  • B: Could you gift-wrap this?
  • A: Sure. We offer free gift wrapping.
  • B: Fine. Iâ€™ll take it.

Discussion

Talk with your teacher about the following question. Refer to the hints if necessary.å’Œè€å¸ˆä¸€èµ·è®¨è®ºä¸€ä¸‹é—®é¢˜ã€‚å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒæ–¹æ¡†ä¸­çš„æç¤ºã€‚

  • 1.Describe a gift that you sent to someone recently(æœ€è¿‘) or in the past.

Hints:
What was the gift?
Who did you send th gift to?
When did you send th gift?

  • 2.Describe a gift that you ever received.

Hints:
What was the gift?
Who gave it to you?
When did he/she send you the gift?
Do you like it? Why or why not?

  • Do you think gifts should be wrapped? Why or why not?

Hints:
yes->more beautiful / give somebody a surpriceâ€¦
no->useless(æ²¡ç”¨çš„)/a waste of papreâ€¦

part c. Review

In this lesson,youâ€™ve learned

  • 5 phrases about â€œchoosing a giftâ€

look for
have something in mind
how about(doing) something
gift-wrap

  • commonly used expressions for buying gifts

How about this one?
Could you gift-wrap this,please?

  • how to talk about topics related to â€œchoosing a giftâ€

Further Study
